So to figure out this problem, we realize that the only other way to do this is to walk near the south pole and circumnavigate it! First, we figure out which line of latitude is 1 mile in circumference. The Equator is about 24,903 miles in circumference, I believe (and I will assume the Earth is a perfect sphere). The circumference of a latitude line is 24,903xcos(latitude) miles. Rearranging we get latitude=inversecos(1/24,903)=89.9977 degrees S
We then workout how many degrees is 1 miles. 1/24,903x360 degrees=0.01446 degrees
We then subtract this from the first latitude, which is what happens when we walk North by 1 mile. 89.9977 degrees-0.01446 degrees=89.9832 degrees South latitude
So the answer is, you start at 89.9832 degrees South latitude (the longitude is irrelevant). You then walk south one mile to 89.9977 degrees South. Then, you walk East one mile and end up at the same point, and finally you walk north one mile back to 89.9832 degrees South latitude and you are finally at the same point you started!

There are an infinite number of solutions:
* The North Pole
* All points which is at a distance of 1+1/(2 pi n) from the South Pole. for any positive integer n.

Why? If we assume the earth is flat when you are up to 1.5 miles from the South Pole (a good approximation), then: You walk 1 mile south. That puts you on a circle whose circumference is 1/n miles. You walk East 1 mile, making n turns around that circle, returning to the point at which you started on the circle, and then head 1 mile north, returning to the origin.

The secret is to have the 1 mile East be the exact circumference of a circle around the south pole. Since the circumference is 1, then the formula C=2*pi*r implies that r=1/(2*pi). We want to begin 1 mile north of any point on that circle, so when we go south 1 mile, then make a circle, and go north 1 mile, we will return to our original location. So choose any point that is located 1+(1/(2*pi)) from the south pole. This result can also be written equivalently as (2pi+1)/(2pi).

But if we assume, that the adventurer goes south, east & north at the beginning and just goes in the same direction, we can phrase the problem like this: We have a line, that goes from the north to the south pole, our y-Coordinate. And we have the applied rotation to the sphere around the axis that goes through both poles, alpha. We want the adventurer to land at the same y-alpha pair, or start and end on the same y-Coordinate that is one of the ends (rotation does nothing to the poles)
If the adventurer goes east, the y-Coordinate doesn't change, as only alpha gets changed.
If we are more than one mile away from the south pole, the y-Coordinate won't change, because we don't pass one of the poles (unless we start & end on one) and therefore can't change the difference in y for going south, and going north is the same thing (because we are now at least one mile away from the north pole). In that area, the only solution is starting at the north pole, because the alpha is always changed and only doesn't matter for the poles.
If we are exactly one mile away from the south pole, we end up at the south pole after going south, and now there isn't any east direction to go to.
If we are less then one mile away, we end up less then one mile away from the south pole after going south, because only one mile was walked. Going east doesn't change the y-Coordinate, and going north increases the distance to the south pole by one mile. So the adventurer can't end up in the same place.
If the diameter of the earth would be small enough (tau*r < 2 miles), it could be possible however: We can't get more than one mile away from the south pole, so only the second case applies, and we are less than one mile away from the north pole after going south.
